author: sebastiengllmt
title: Fracada Addressing Audit
description: Fracada is a fractionalized NFT project for Cardano. It was audited thanks to a Catalyst proposal in the previous round and now we need funds to implement the audit

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the challenge of bringing impactful use cases to Cardano, however the extent of this impact is not clear from this proposal so I have rated it 4/5 (agree, but not strongly agree). While fractionalized NFT's are an interesting use case, the proposal does not explain how this will impact Cardano, or to what extent. Being a freely available open source project means anyone can use this Code. If this is deployed without correcting the issues found in the audit, they may be a risk of users loosing their funds, so it is important to complete this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: The DCspark team has the relevant skills and abilities to implement this proposal, and they have already built out the project, they only need to address the concerns of the completed audit. https://www.dcspark.io/#founders The team has delivered Milkomedia and Flint wallet, and this would be a relatively small project for this experienced team.
f6_assessments.q2: It is unclear from the proposal how much work is involved with addressing the audit concerns, or how long they estimate it will take. The timeline is an estimated completion in Q3 of this year, but this is not very specific. The typical voter may not understand how much work is required, or how long it will take, so further explanation of the process would improve the clarity/auditability of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a proposal by dcSpark, a company that has worked on multiple proposals in the last Catalyst funds. In this case, they are requesting funds in order to implement the changes required by an audit which was performed on an NFT project of theirs, that was again built with Catalyst funding (https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/384625-48088). The benefit to the community in solving these issues according to the proposer is that this fractionalized NFT project is open source and parts of it can be used by any person or team who wants to start their own project. We can think of it as a template which has already built functionalities which can be used by other people, such as an upgradeable treasury, a voting dApp etc.
As risks, the proposer identifies regular development concerns like delays or inappropriate budgeting and also the fact that even if the project passes the audit after the initial problems are fixed, that is not a guarantee that no bugs at all remain. It’s good that these were identified, but the proposer should also have mentioned how they plan to mitigate these risks.
Nevertheless, I agree that working on tools and templates which can help more people start building on Cardano (NFT projects in this case) does effectively address the Dapps, Products & Integrations challenge. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q1: We are not provided with a detailed timeline or roadmap to help build a case for Feasibility, we are just informed that the plan is to address the issues pointed out by the audit in Q3. We are also not provided with the details of the person who will be working on this audit, except that they will be a Plutus developer, most likely an employee of dcSpark. To be honest, there is a severe lack of information in this section, which is only remediated by the fact that dcSpark has a good reputation and has been building products in the Cardano ecosystem for a long time now. Still, a new team would not be able to get funding in my opinion without providing details about their members, about their detailed plan for the project, about the budget and how it will be used (detailed time + task estimations) etc. 15000 USD is not a big ask for what seems to be the benefit here, but again, we are relying more on speculation than transparent information. I agree that the proposal is likely to be implemented successfully due to dcSpark being the company behind it, but please consider bringing up your proposals to the Catalyst standard as outlined by the proposer guide (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oE_cnP0gksdAanXV4w5DYaDNp_tbYEvyHhTUG4HYZ3Q/edit#). Score: 4
f6_assessments.q2:
As with the previous section, we are given almost no information here on how the project’s progress and success can be tracked. Addressing the auditor’s concerns and releasing the code, as stated by the proposer, is not information that the community can use to track progress. For this, we would need to at least know a few examples of the issues that were found and then a few key progress indicators (for example “informing the community when a pull request with a fix for X issue has been created and having at least one of these every two weeks in Q3 etc”). Auditability requires detailed planning with hard numbers which later have to be met. Otherwise, the community simply has to trust you when you say that you’re making progress or have completed the proposal. It’s good that we have been provided with a link to the project’s github (https://github.com/dcSpark/fracada), but we would also need something more non-programmer friendly where updates on the projects are posted (for example a dashboard for your catalyst proposals).
Since I know how competent this company is in delivering solutions for Cardano, I will score 4 here, but please consider adding the information I mentioned above to future proposals, because the aim of Catalyst is for us, the community, to be able to verify the projects we are funding.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is looking to improve an existing product called Fracada based on an audit that was funded by a previous catalyst proposal.  The proposal explains that Fracada is an open source fractionalized NFT project that anyone can use as their own or as a reference, and so if they address the concerns found in the audit, it can only be beneficial to those people who use their code. This makes sense, but I wish there was more info given about what Fracada actually is.  This would help voters decide if they believe funding for these improvements is even worth it. They do provide a link to the github where the Fracada code is located, but I think giving a brief summary of what it does in the proposal would still be good.  I think providing some stats about how many people use the Fracada code would also help the community understand the impact that these improvements would have.  Currently I don’t know how used the Fracada code is, so it is difficult for me to assess if addressing the concerns of the audit will have a significant impact on the Cardano ecosystem or not.
f6_assessments.q1:
First of all the dcSpark team is the team behind Milkomeda, which is an EVM sidechain for Cardano, so they definitely have competent and reliable developers based on how they were able to produce that securely.

In this proposal they explain they’ve built different products for Cardano but there’s not much info about the specific developer that they will have working on this proposal. I think some more info about them would be good, but perhaps they haven’t decided which developer will be working on it yet.  Besides that, the main problem I have with this proposal is the lack of a detailed plan and budget breakdown.  I can understand the budget breakdown not being very detailed because it seems like the funding is only going towards the compensation of the developer who works on this proposal, and there’s not much to break down about that.  They could have included the hours they estimate this proposal to take though, just for more clarity behind how the amount was decided on.

The detailed plan section of the proposal could definitely use more details because currently it only states that they plan to address the concerns of the audit in Q3 of this year.  Surely some more details could’ve been added about what steps they plan to take to address the concerns, even if they don’t want to reveal what concerns the audit had yet.  The steps could even be as simple as “Research, develop, and testing,” and then provide general estimates about how long they plan each step to take.

Based on the reliability and the experience of the dcSpark team, I do genuinely believe this proposal would be implemented successfully. However, they do not do a good job of showcasing their preparedness in this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The only thing provided for auditability is a github link where we can watch for development being made. This is definitely useful, and honestly, not much more is needed for auditability of this proposal because of its simplicity.  The main thing I would’ve liked to see is some milestones to watch for, like finished researching, or finished QA testing.  Normally I would like to see some KPIs too, but I’m having a difficult time coming up with possible KPIs for indicating they were successful in addressing the concerns of the audit.  Especially since no info is provided about what concerns are in the audit.

f6_assessments.q0:
To understand what problem this proposal solves, I have to go back to the original proposal called: "Segmented NFT v2". To better understand the solution the author and their team wanted to come up with in this Challenge.
I kept learning about the Fracada dApp to see what it was all about. From the link to the source code they provide on Github.
I finally understood that this is a public protocol and source code. This is a place where this contract locks an NFT and mints a number of tokens representing fractions of it. To get the NFT back, a segmentation code is written.
If you don't persevere and don't dig deep, you won't understand the benefit the author wants to present in this proposal.
What they want here is to check the source code of Fracada V2 to make sure it's bug-free. If they don't check that source code and it gets copied by developers to create other dApps.
In case the source code has no errors, that's okay. But if something goes wrong, it will be a disaster for Cardano. This will create a security hole for the bad guys to exploit and take away the money of the investors on Cardano.
The author and team want to ensure the security of the Cardano ecosystem so that the risks are minimal. After carefully studying the solution proposed by the author, I believe that this proposal is extremely important for the future development of Cardano.
If they provided more information, I think it would be perfect

f6_assessments.q2:

As reviewers, the new offer will give them a very low score because of the information they provide. But if you take a close look at their personal profiles and work achievements at the dcspark.io website, chances are other recommended reviewers will think twice and give them a different score.
I've been following their team for a long time and it's arguably the strongest outside development team on Cardano right now. So they don't need to say much, I will still give them 4 stars because I believe they will do more than they say and do a great job on this recommendation. I only regret that they don't provide as much information as other suggestions.

f6_assessments.q0: Proposers have ben previously funded for a fractionalized NFT project for Cardano. Personally, I didn’t previously review the prior proposals so have no awareness of the details possibly mentioned. Proposers would benefit from quickly outlining the aims of the project for new Pas or those who didn’t review their proposal in the last funding cycle. This could be achieved by quickly outlining the issue or problem and explaining how their project looks to resolve it. The fact they were funded does suggest that the impact was deemed appropriate by the catalyst community. The project looks to be funded in order to deal with issues found by an auditor which demonstrates an improvement of the existing service to provide a better platform for users-meeting challenge objectives. The project is said to be open source and proposers could benefit from detailing further (it is briefly mentioned) how this could result in new use cases. Access to an open-source successful project could bring in develops to the Cardano ecosystem with an existing layout to follow. Proposers have done well to detail how the audit of the code will not only benefit fradaca but the projects that look to use the fradaca aa a reference. Further explanation of how the service looks to provide value for the community would also prove valuable Identification of existing platforms and the current pitfalls they have in comparison to the proposed platform would help highlight its value. I assume proposers kept this section brief due to the fact they were allocated funding based on the same proposal. Due to the previous funding allocated and the team looking to improve on the project I will deem the proposal as impactful.
f6_assessments.q1: When asked to provide a plan proposers claim to plan to address audit concerns in q3. As a time frame not, enough information is provided to judge whether feasible. Proposers should consider detailing the results of the audit and provide a month-by-month breakdown from July to September. This breakdown should detail the work required and possible estimates regarding time and cost. At this moment with the information provided the plan does not qualify as feasible with no true timeline or key milestones being provided. In regard to the budget or funding is to be allocated to one Plutus developer (correct identification of required persons) who appears yet to be contacted. This is appropriate based on the team’s goals but providing a hourly breakdown would serve beneficial displaying a awareness of the amount of work that is required. This alongside details of the Plutus developers’ credentials and possible previous projects would provide more confidence in the feasibility. Proposers could also look to define the sustainability of the project after the issues found in auditing are dealt with. No plans to return for funding are mentioned but proposers fail to elaborate on why, if the project looks to be self-sustaining proposers should detail how this will be achieved (examples being a charging users).
f6_assessments.q2: The team don’t mention how they plan to track the progress but do mention releasing the code that resolves the concerns of the auditor. Explaining where this code will be released (GitHub for example) would prove beneficial as a lack of specification of where results will be posted doesn’t allow for auditability. Proposers should consider posting when critical milestones (resolving one of auditor’s concerns) are met and look to inform the community. This would allow for the community to audit whether the rework of the code has successfully rectified the issues posed by the auditor. Success is accurately defined as addressing auditor concerns but no kpis are provided. Without provision of the auditor concerns success cannot be audited. In future proposers should look to detail this. Unfortunately, at this moment the information provided doesn’t allow for it to be audited.

solution: The funds will be used for a Plutus developer to address the concerns found in the audit, followed by publishing the audit and updated code for the community
experience: The dcSpark team has written multiple MIT open source Plutus contracts for the community to use freely such as an upgradeable treasury, a voting dApp and Fracada.
